margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is normally in the range <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>11.3</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>14.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">11.3-14.0 \mathrm{kPa}(80-100 \mathrm{mmHg})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">11.3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">14.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">kPa</span></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">âˆ’</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Any lung disease that interferes with gas exchange may reduce arterial <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PaO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">â€‹</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="imaging-the-lung-and-chest">Imaging the lung and chest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#imaging-the-lung-and-chest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-chest-x-ray">The chest X-ray<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-chest-x-ray" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The chest X-ray is an important extension of the clinical examination (Box 10.9). This is particularly so in patients with respiratory symptoms,</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-10-9-points-to-note-when-assessing-the-chest-x-ray">Box 10.9 Points to note when assessing the chest X-ray<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-10-9-points-to-note-when-assessing-the-chest-x-ray" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Name of patient and date (and time) of X-ray</li>
<li>Bony skeleton</li>
<li>Position of the patient</li>
<li>Position of the trachea</li>
<li>Outline of heart</li>
<li>Outline of mediastinum</li>
<li>Diaphragm</li>
<li>Lung fields</li>
</ul>
<p>and a normal X-ray taken some time before the development of symptoms should therefore not be accepted as a reason for not taking an up-to-date film. In many instances, it is of great value to have previous X-rays for comparison, but if these are lacking then careful follow up with subsequent films may provide the necessary information.</p>
<p>The standard chest X-ray is a posteroanterior (PA) view taken with the film against the front of the patient's chest and the X-ray source 2 m behind the patient (see Fig. 10.4). The X-ray is examined systematically on a viewing box or computer screen, according to the following plan and referring to the thoracic anatomy described at the beginning of this chapter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-position-of-the-patient">The position of the patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-position-of-the-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is the patient straight or rotated? If straight, the inner ends of the clavicles will be equidistant from the midline of the vertebral body. This is important because any rotation will tend particularly to alter the appearance of the mediastinum and the hilar shadows.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-outline-of-the-heart-and-the-mediastinum">The outline of the heart and the mediastinum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-outline-of-the-heart-and-the-mediastinum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is this normal in size, shape and position?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-position-of-the-trachea">The position of the trachea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-position-of-the-trachea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is seen as a dark column representing the air within the trachea. Is the trachea centrally placed or deviated to either side?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-diaphragm">The diaphragm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-diaphragm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Can the diaphragm be seen on each side? Is it normal in shape and position? Normally, the anterior end of the sixth or seventh rib crosses the mid-part of the diaphragm on each side, although the diaphragm on the right is usually a little higher than on the left. Are the cardiophrenic angles clearly seen?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lung-fields">The lung fields<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lung-fields" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For radiological purposes, the lung fields are divided into three zones:
1 The upper zone extends from the apex to a line drawn through the lower borders of the anterior ends of the second costal cartilages.
2 The mid-zone extends from this line to one drawn through the lower borders of the fourth costal cartilages.
3 The lower zone extends from this line to the bases of the lungs.
Each zone is systematically examined on both sides, and any area that appears abnormal is carefully compared with the corresponding area on the opposite side. The horizontal fissure, which separates the right upper and middle lobes, may sometimes be seen running horizontally in the third and fourth interspaces on the right side.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-bony-skeleton">The bony skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-bony-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Is the chest symmetrical?</li>
<li>Is scoliosis present?</li>
<li>Are the ribs unduly crowded or widely spaced in any area?</li>
<li>Are cervical ribs present?</li>
<li>Are any ribs eroded or absent?</li>
</ul>
<p>As well as the standard AP view, lateral views are sometimes carried out to help localize any lesion that is seen. In examining a lateral view, as in Figure 10.8, follow this plan:</p>
<ul>
<li>Identify the sternum anteriorly and the vertebral bodies posteriorly. The cardiac shadow lies anteriorly and inferiorly.</li>
<li>There should be a lucent (dark) area retrosternally which has approximately the same density as the area posterior to the heart and anterior to the vertebral bodies. Check for any difference between the two, or for any discrete lesion in either area.</li>
<li>Check for any collapsed vertebrae.</li>
<li>The lowest vertebrae should appear darkest, becoming whiter as they progress superiorly. Interruption of this smooth gradation suggests an abnormality overlying the vertebral bodies involved.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a237922a.jpeg" alt="img-84.jpeg"></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 10.8 A lateral chest X-ray.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-67280ef0.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.9 A CT-generated 3D reconstruction demonstrating that the patient has a tracheal stenosis (arrowed). (Courtesy of Professor R.H. Reznek.)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-computed-tomography-scan">The computed tomography scan<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-computed-tomography-scan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The routine chest X-ray consists of shadows at all depths in the chest superimposed on one another. In computed tomography (CT) scanning, X-rays are passed through the body at different angles and the resulting information is processed by computer to generate a series of cross-sectional images. A thoracic CT scan thus comprises a series of cross-sectional 'slices' through the thorax at various levels.
The CT scan is a vital part of the staging of lung cancer, and inoperability may be demonstrated by evidence on CT of mediastinal involvement. CT scanning will demonstrate the presence of dilated and distorted bronchi, as in bronchiectasis. Diffuse pulmonary fibrosis will be shown by a modified high-resolution/thin-section scan technique. Emboli in the pulmonary arteries can be demonstrated by a rapid data acquisition spiral CT technique, and has advantages over isotope lung scanning (see below) in diagnosing pulmonary embolism in patients with pre-existing lung disease. Many scanners can now generate three-dimensional representations of the thoracic structures (Fig. 10.9).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="radioisotope-imaging">Radioisotope imaging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#radioisotope-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the lungs, the most widely used radioisotope technique is combined ventilation and perfusion scanning, used to aid the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.
The perfusion scan is performed by injecting intravenously a small dose of macroaggregated human albumin particles labelled with technetium-99m
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>99</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></mrow><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left({ }^{99 \mathrm{~m}} \mathrm{Tc}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">99</span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mspace nobreak mtight"><span class="mtight">&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Tc</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. A gamma-camera image is then built up of the radioactive particles impacted in the pulmonary vasculature; the distribution of perfusion in the lung can then be seen. The ventilation scan is obtained by inhalation of a radioactive gas such as krypton<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>81</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>81</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">81 \mathrm{~m}\left({ }^{81 \mathrm{~m}} \mathrm{Kr}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="mord">81</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">(</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">81</span><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mspace nobreak mtight"><span class="mtight">&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">m</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Kr</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, again using scanning to identify the distribution of the radioactivity.
Blood is usually diverted away from areas of the lung that are unventilated, so a matched defect on both the ventilation and perfusion scans usually indicates parenchymal lung disease. If there are areas of ventilated lung which are not perfused (i.e. an unmatched defect), this is evidence in support of an embolism to the unperfused area. Figure 10.10 shows a ventilation-perfusion isotope scan. The unmatched defects (areas ventilated by the inspired air but not perfused by blood) suggest a high probability of pulmonary embolism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="magnetic-resonance-imaging">Magnetic resonance imaging<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#magnetic-resonance-imaging" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is useful in demonstrating mediastinal abnormalities and can help evaluate invasion of the mediastinum and chest wall by tumour. Apart from the fact that it does not use ionizing radiation, currently it has few other advantages over CT in imaging the thorax. MRI is particularly degraded by movement artefact in imaging the chest, because of the relatively long data acquisition time, but faster scanners are beginning to overcome this drawback.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ultrasound">Ultrasound<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ultrasound" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ultrasound reveals much less detail than CT scanning but has the advantages that it does not involve radiation and, as it gives 'real-time' images, the operator can visualize what is happening as it happens.
Ultrasound is used for examining diaphragmatic movement. A paralysed hemidiaphragm usually results from damage to the phrenic nerve by a mediastinal tumour. If the patient is asked to make a sudden inspiratory effort, as in sniffing, the nonparalysed side of the diaphragm moves down, so intrathoracic pressure drops, and the paralysed side moves up.
Ultrasound is also valuable in distinguishing pleural thickening from pleural fluid. With real-time imaging, the latter can be seen to move with changes in posture. When such fluid is present, ultrasound may be used to aid placement of a catheter to drain the collection, and also to steer a draining catheter accurately into an intrapulmonary abscess.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="positron-emission-tomography-pet-scanning">Positron emission tomography (PET) scanning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#positron-emission-tomography-pet-scanning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this technique, a radiolabelled 18-flurodeoxyglucose (FDG) molecule is administered, which is taken up by metabolically active tissues, such as cancers,</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-c2b24031.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.10 Ventilation/perfusion isotope scan of the lungs. Segmental and subsegmental loss of perfusion (B &amp; D) can be seen with relatively normal ventilation (A &amp; C). The clear punched-out areas in the perfusion (B &amp; D) scans indicate areas of reduced isotope concentration during the perfusion scan. Thus these are areas of reduced blood flow. The ventilation scans show normal aeration of the lungs as depicted by the isotope distribution in the pulmonary airways. These sequences of scans are suggestive of pulmonary embolism because they show impaired perfusion with normal ventilation.
showing as 'hot spots' on the image. It is useful in detecting regional and mediastinal lymphadenopathy and is now widely used to assess suitability for surgery in patients with lung cancer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="flexible-bronchoscopy">Flexible bronchoscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#flexible-bronchoscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bronchoscopy is an essential tool in the investigation of many forms of respiratory disease. For discrete abnormalities, such as a mass seen on chest X-ray and suspected to be a lung cancer, bronchoscopy is usually indicated to investigate its nature. Under local anaesthesia, the flexible bronchoscope is passed through the nose, pharynx and larynx, down the trachea, and the bronchial tree is then inspected. Figure 10.11 shows a lung cancer seen down the bronchoscope. Flexible biopsy forceps are passed down a channel inside the bronchoscope, and are used to obtain tissue samples for histological examination. Similarly, aspirated bronchial secretions and brushings of any endobronchial abnormality can be sent to the laboratory for cytological examination.
At bronchoscopy, specimens are also taken for microbiological examination in order to determine the nature of any infecting organisms. In diffuse interstitial lung disease, such as sarcoidosis or pulmonary fibrosis, the technique of transbronchial
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-25aadae1.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg"></p>
<p>Figure 10.11 A lung cancer, seen down the bronchoscope.
biopsy can be used to obtain small specimens of lung parenchyma for histological examination to help confirm the diagnosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pleural-aspiration-and-biopsy">Pleural aspiration and biopsy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-aspiration-and-biopsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A pleural effusion can give rise to diagnostic problems and, sometimes, management problems when the amount of fluid causes respiratory embarrassment. When a pleural effusion is seen as a</p>
<p>presenting feature in a middle-aged or older patient, the most likely cause is a malignancy. Less commonly, particularly in younger patients, it may be due to tuberculosis. In either case, the diagnosis is best obtained by both aspiration of the fluid and pleural biopsy. Aspiration alone has a lower diagnostic yield.</p>
<p>After anaesthetizing the skin, subcutaneous tissues and pleura, pleural fluid may be aspirated by syringe and needle for microbiological and cytological examination. Large pleural effusions may need to be drained by an indwelling catheter, left in situ until the fluid has been fully removed. As noted above, ultrasound guidance can be helpful, particularly if the fluid is loculated in various pockets.</p>
<p>Cytological examination of pleural fluid may demonstrate the presence of malignant cells. Many polymorphs may be seen if the effusion is secondary to an underlying pneumonic infection. With tuberculosis, the fluid usually contains many lymphocytes, although tubercle bacilli are rarely seen. Therefore, almost all pleural fluid samples should be cultured for possible tuberculosis, because this infection can coexist with other pathologies and it is so important not to miss it. In empyema, pus is present in the pleural cavity. It has a characteristic appearance and is full of white cells and organisms.</p>
<p>The pleural fluid should also be examined for protein content. A transudate (resulting from cardiac or renal failure) can be distinguished from an exudate (from pleural inflammation or malignancy) by its lower protein content ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>30</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;30 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{l}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">l</span></span></span></span></span> ). Light's criteria may also be applied (Box 10.10).</p>
<p>Biopsies of the pleura can be obtained percutaneously and under local anaesthesia using an Abram's pleural biopsy needle. This technique can be used when there is pleural fluid present to obtain pleural tissue for histological examination and, whenever tuberculosis is a possibility, for microbiological culture. If ultrasound or CT examination shows the pleura to be thickened, biopsies may be obtained</p>
<p>Box 10.10 Light's criteria for diagnosing a pleural effusion</p>
<p>An effusion is exudative if it meets one of the following criteria:</p>
<ul>

under image guidance by Abram's needle, a Tru-cut needle and similar techniques.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thoracoscopy">Thoracoscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thoracoscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This technique enables the pleural cavity to be examined directly and biopsies taken under direct vision. The procedure is commonly performed under a general anaesthetic by a surgeon who uses a rigid thoracoscope after the lung has been deflated. Increasingly, however, more minimally invasive procedures using flexible thoracoscopes attached to cameras are being used (video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery or VATS).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lung-biopsy">Lung biopsy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-biopsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>As noted above, the technique of transbronchial biopsy can be used to obtain samples of lung parenchyma, but often samples are too small for diagnosis. In this circumstance, biopsies of the lung taken at thoracoscopy may be of value. Occasionally, a formal open lung biopsy obtained at thoracotomy may be necessary.</p>
<p>When there is a discrete, localized lesion, it may be possible to obtain a biopsy percutaneously with the aid of CT scanning to direct the insertion of the biopsy needle (Fig. 10.12).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immunological-tests">Immunological tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immunological-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Asthma attacks may be due to type I immediate hypersensitivity reactions on exposure to common environmental proteins known as allergens. In such

individuals, an inherited tendency to produce exaggerated levels of immunogobulin E (IgE) against these allergens is responsible. Part of the assessment of such allergic patients might include skin-prick tests (see Ch. 15). Alternatively, serum levels of specific (individual) IgEs against allergens may be measured by blood tests (formerly known as RAST tests) to demonstrate sensitization. The total IgE level is often raised in patients with asthma, rhinitis or eczema. Delayed (type IV, cell-mediated) hypersensitivity is shown by the Mantoux and Heaf skin tests, used to detect the presence of sensitivity to tuberculin protein. Precipitating immunoglobulin G <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{IgG})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">IgG</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> antibodies in the circulating blood are present in patients with some fungal diseases, such as bronchopulmonary aspergillosis or aspergilloma. In patients suspected of having an allergic alveolitis, IgG antibodies may be demonstrated to the relevant antigens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-images">Clinical images<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-images" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Figures 10.13-10.18 illustrate some of the clinical points of this chapter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiovascular-system">Cardiovascular system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiovascular-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Adam D. Timmis and Andrew Archbold</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The twentieth century saw major changes in patterns of cardiovascular disease. In the developed world, syphilitic and tuberculous involvement of the cardiovascular system became rare, and the incidence of rheumatic disease declined considerably. On the other hand, myocardial and conducting tissue disease were diagnosed with increasing frequency and the importance of arterial hypertension became recognized. Coronary artery disease emerged as the major cardiovascular disorder of the era, becoming the most common cause of premature death throughout Europe, North America and Australasia. In the last 30 years, there has been a steady fall in age-specific death rates from coronary artery disease in Western societies, but elsewhere its prevalence is increasing and in the underdeveloped world it now threatens to overtake malnutrition and infectious disease as the major cause of death.</p>
<p>As patterns of cardiovascular disease changed, so did the cardiologist's diagnostic tools. A century that started with the stethoscope, the sphygmomanometer, the chest X-ray and a very rudimentary electrocardiogram saw the development of a variety of new imaging modalities, using ultrasound, radioisotopes, X-rays and magnetic resonance. This non-invasive capability was complemented by introduction of the catheterization laboratory, permitting angiographic imaging, electrophysiological recording and tissue biopsy of the heart. Add to this the resources of the chemical pathology, bacteriology and molecular biology laboratories, and the array of diagnostic technology available to the modern cardiologist becomes almost overwhelming. Nevertheless, most of the common cardiac disorders encountered in clinical practice can still be diagnosed at the bedside on the basis of a careful history and physical examination. Indeed, this simple fact defines the true art of cardiology and remains as
relevant now as it was before recent technological advances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-cardiac-history">The cardiac history<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cardiac-history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The history should record details of presenting symptoms, of which the most common are chest pain, fatigue and dyspnoea, palpitations, and presyncope or syncope (see below and Box 11.1). Previous illness should also be recorded, as it may provide important clues about the cardiac diagnosis - thyroid, connective tissue and neoplastic disorders, for example, can all affect the heart. Rheumatic fever in childhood is important because of its association with valvular heart disease; and diabetes and dyslipidaemias because of their association with coronary artery disease. Smoking is a major risk factor for coronary artery disease. Alcohol abuse predisposes to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy. The cardiac history should quantify both habits in terms of pack-years smoked and units of alcohol consumed. The family history should always be documented because coronary artery disease and hypertension often run in families, as do some of the less common cardiovascular disorders, such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Indeed, in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, a family history of sudden death is probably the single most important indicator of risk. Finally, the drug history should be recorded, as many commonly prescribed drugs are potentially cardiotoxic. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Î²</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">Î²</span></span></span></span></span>-Blockers and some calcium channel blockers (diltiazem, verapamil), for example, can cause symptomatic bradycardias, and tricyclic antidepressants and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Î²</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">Î²</span></span></span></span></span> agonists can cause tachyarrhythmias. Vasodilators cause variable reductions in blood pressure which can lead to syncopal attacks, particularly in patients with aortic stenosis. The myocardial toxicity of certain cytotoxic drugs (notably doxorubicin and related compounds) is an important cause of cardiomyopathy.</p>
<p>Box 11.1 Structure for the cardiac history Presenting complaint (PC)</p>
<ul>
<li>The symptom that prompts the patient to seek medical attention - commonly chest pain, breathlessness (dyspnoea), palpitation, dizziness or blackouts (syncope)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history-of-presenting-complaint-hpc">History of presenting complaint (HPC)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history-of-presenting-complaint-hpc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This should define the nature of the symptoms, initially through open questioning. Closed questions are used to elicit the presence or absence of features which help to differentiate between diagnoses:</li>
<li>Chest pain: site, radiation, character, duration, provoking and relieving factors, associated symptoms?</li>
<li>Breathlessness: orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, ankle swelling, cough, wheeze, haemoptysis?</li>
<li>Palpitation: sudden onset and offset, 'thumps' or 'pauses', presyncope or syncope?</li>
<li>Dizziness/syncope: provoking factors, warning, duration, recovery?</li>
</ul>
<p>Risk factors for cardiovascular disease</p>
<ul>
<li>Smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, diabetes, family history of premature vascular disease</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="past-medical-history-pmh">Past medical history (PMH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#past-medical-history-pmh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Stroke or transient ischaemic attack (TIA), renal impairment, rheumatic fever, peripheral vascular disease, other</li>
<li>Operations, hospital clinic attendances</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="family-history">Family history<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#family-history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac disease, sudden death</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drug-history">Drug history<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-history" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Include quantification of alcohol intake</li>
<li>If a patient with known cardiovascular disease is not taking the recognized standard treatment, the reason for this should be established. For example, why no statin treatment in a patient with previous myocardial infarction? - 'Because it caused muscle pains'</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chest-pain">Chest pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chest-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Myocardial ischaemia, pericarditis, aortic dissection and pulmonary embolism are the most common causes of acute, severe chest pain. Chronic, recurrent chest pain is usually caused by angina, oesophageal reflux or musculoskeletal pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myocardial-ischaemia">Myocardial ischaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-ischaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ischaemia of the heart results from an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand, producing pain called angina (Boxes 11.2 and 11.3). Angina is usually a symptom of atherosclerotic coronary artery disease, which impedes myocardial</p>
<p>Box 11.2 Angina</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="typical-patient">Typical patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typical-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Middle-aged or elderly man or woman often with a family history of coronary heart disease and one or more of the major reversible risk factors (smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, diabetes)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-symptoms">Major symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Exertional chest pain and shortness of breath. Pain often described as 'heaviness' or 'tightness', and may radiate into arms, neck or jaw</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-signs">Major signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>None, although hypertension and signs of hyperlipidaemia (xanthelasmata, xanthomas) may be present</li>
<li>Peripheral vascular disease, evidenced by absent pulses or arterial bruits, is commonly associated with coronary heart disease</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Typical history is most important diagnostic tool</li>
<li>Electrocardiogram (ECG): often normal; may show Q waves in patients with previous myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Exercise ECG test: exertional ST depression</li>
<li>Isotope or magnetic resonance perfusion scan: stress-induced perfusion defects</li>
<li>Coronary angiogram: confirms coronary artery disease</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-investigations">Additional investigations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Blood sugar and lipids to rule out diabetes and dyslipidaemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="comments">Comments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A careful history is the single most important means of diagnosing angina</li>
</ul>
<p>Box 11.3 Causes of angina
Impaired myocardial oxygen supply</p>
<ul>
<li>Coronary artery disease:</li>
<li>atherosclerosis</li>
<li>arteritis in connective tissue disorders</li>
<li>diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>Coronary artery spasm</li>
<li>Congenital coronary artery disease:</li>
<li>arteriovenous fistula</li>
<li>anomalous origin from pulmonary artery</li>
<li>Severe anaemia or hypoxia</li>
</ul>
<p>Increased myocardial oxygen demand</p>
<ul>
<li>Left ventricular hypertrophy:</li>
<li>hypertension</li>
<li>aortic valve disease</li>
<li>hypertrophic cardiomyopathy</li>
<li>Tachyarrhythmias</li>
</ul>
<p>Box 11.4 Causes of coronary artery disease</p>
<ul>
<li>Atherosclerosis</li>
<li>Arteritis:</li>
<li>systemic lupus erythematosus</li>
<li>polyarteritis nodosa</li>
<li>rheumatoid arthritis</li>
<li>ankylosing spondylitis</li>
<li>syphilis</li>
<li>Takayasu's disease</li>
<li>Coronary dissection:</li>
<li>spontaneous</li>
<li>catheter or angioplasty induced</li>
<li>Embolism:</li>
<li>infective endocarditis</li>
<li>left atrial/ventricular thrombus</li>
<li>left atrial/ventricular tumour</li>
<li>prosthetic valve thrombus</li>
<li>paradoxical embolism</li>
<li>complication of cardiac catheterization</li>
<li>Coronary mural thickening:</li>
<li>amyloidosis</li>
<li>radiation therapy</li>
<li>Hurler's disease</li>
<li>pseudoxanthoma elasticum</li>
<li>Other causes of coronary luminal narrowing:</li>
<li>aortic dissection</li>
<li>coronary spasm</li>
<li>Congenital coronary artery disease:</li>
<li>anomalous origin from pulmonary artery</li>
<li>arteriovenous fistula
oxygen supply. Other causes of coronary artery disease (Box 11.4) are rare. However, it is important to be vigilant for causes of angina due to increased myocardial oxygen demand, such as aortic stenosis. The history is diagnostic for angina if the location of the pain, its character, its relation to exertion and its duration are typical. The patient describes retrosternal pain which may radiate into the arms, the throat or the jaw. It has a constricting character, is provoked by exertion and relieved within minutes by rest. The patient's threshold for angina is typically reduced after eating or in cold weather due to the diversion of blood to the gut and the increased myocardial work consequent upon peripheral vasoconstriction, respectively. Occasionally angina is provoked only by the first significant activity of the day, a phenomenon known as the 'warm-up effect' and due to myocardial preconditioning. Less commonly, myocardial ischaemia may manifest as breathlessness, fatigue or symptoms that the patient finds difficult to describe - 'I just have to stop' - in which case the clues to the diagnosis are the relation of symptoms to exertion, the presence of risk factors for coronary artery disease and the absence of an alternative explanation for the symptoms, such as heart failure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="box-11-5-acute-coronary-syndromes">Box 11.5 Acute coronary syndromes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#box-11-5-acute-coronary-syndromes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="typical-patient">Typical patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typical-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Middle-aged (male) or elderly (either sex) patient, often with a family history of coronary heart disease and one or more of the major reversible risk factors (smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, diabetes)</li>
<li>In many patients, there is no preceding history of angina</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-symptoms">Major symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chest pain and shortness of breath. Pain usually prolonged and often described as 'heaviness' or 'tightness', with radiation into arms, neck or jaw. Alternative descriptions include 'congestion' or 'burning', which may be confused with indigestion</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-signs">Major signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Frequently none</li>
<li>Autonomic disturbance, sweating, vomiting implies myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Tachycardia (anterior myocardial infarction), bradycardia (inferior myocardial infarction)</li>
<li>Fourth heart sound, dyskinetic precordial impulse, pulmonary oedema with large infarcts</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(STEMI <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span></span></span></span></span> ST elevation myocardial infarction)</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;">STEMI</th><th style="text-align: left;">Non-STEMI</th><th style="text-align: left;">Unstable &lt;br&gt; angina</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">ECG</td><td style="text-align: left;">ST &lt;br&gt; elevation</td><td style="text-align: left;">Normal, ST &lt;br&gt; depression, &lt;br&gt; T-wave &lt;br&gt; inversion</td><td style="text-align: left;">Normal, ST &lt;br&gt; depression, &lt;br&gt; T-wave &lt;br&gt; inversion</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cardiac &lt;br&gt; biomarkers, &lt;br&gt; e.g. troponin &lt;br&gt; I or T</td><td style="text-align: left;">Raised</td><td style="text-align: left;">Raised</td><td style="text-align: left;">Normal</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-investigations">Additional investigations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Biochemistry: blood sugar and lipids to rule out diabetes and dyslipidaemia</li>
<li>Risk stratification: echocardiogram (left ventricular function), coronary angiogram in high-risk patients, perfusion imaging in low-risk patients</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="comments">Comments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>History and troponin testing most useful diagnostic tools in non-ST elevation acute coronary syndromes</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-coronary-syndromes">Acute coronary syndromes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-coronary-syndromes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In these life-threatening cardiac emergencies, the pain is similar in location and character to angina but is usually more severe, more prolonged and unrelieved by rest (Box 11.5).</p>
<p>Box 11.8 Causes of acute pericarditis</p>
<ul>
<li>Idiopathic</li>
<li>Infective:</li>
<li>viral (Coxsackie B, influenza, herpes simplex)</li>
<li>bacterial (Staphylococcus aureus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis)</li>
<li>Connective tissue disease:</li>
<li>systemic lupus erythematosus</li>
<li>rheumatoid arthritis</li>
<li>polyarteritis nodosa</li>
<li>Uraemia</li>
<li>Malignancy (e.g. breast, lung, lymphoma, leukaemia)</li>
<li>Radiation therapy</li>
<li>Acute myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Post-myocardial infarction/cardiotomy (Dressler's syndrome)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pericarditis">Pericarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pericarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This causes central chest pain, which is sharp in character and aggravated by deep inspiration, cough or postural changes. Characteristically, the pain is exacerbated by lying recumbent and reduced by sitting forward. Pericarditis is usually idiopathic or caused by Coxsackie B infection. It may also occur as a complication of myocardial infarction, but other causes are seen less commonly (Box 11.6).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aortic-dissection">Aortic dissection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aortic-dissection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This produces severe tearing pain in either the front or the back of the chest. The onset is abrupt, unlike the crescendo quality of ischaemic cardiac pain (Box 11.7).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-embolism">Pulmonary embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peripheral pulmonary embolism causes suddenonset sharp, pleuritic chest pain, breathlessness and haemoptysis. Major, central pulmonary embolism presents with breathlessness, chest pain that can be indistinguishable from ischaemic chest pains and syncope. Risk factors for pulmonary embolism should be sought in the history (Box 11.8).</p>
<p>Rare cardiovascular causes of chest pain include mitral valve disease associated with massive left atrial dilatation. This causes discomfort in the back, sometimes associated with dysphagia due to oesophageal compression. Aortic aneurysms can also cause pain in the chest owing to local compression.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dyspnoea">Dyspnoea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dyspnoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dyspnoea is an abnormal awareness of breathing occurring either at rest or at an unexpectedly low level of exertion. It is a major symptom of many cardiac disorders, particularly left heart failure</p>
<p>Box 11.7 Aortic dissection
Typical patient</p>
<ul>
<li>Middle-aged or elderly patient with a history of hypertension or arteriosclerotic disease</li>
<li>Occasionally younger patient with aortic root disease (e.g. Marfan's syndrome)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-symptoms">Major symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chest pain, typically interscapular</li>
</ul>
<p>Major signs</p>
<ul>
<li>Often none</li>
<li>Sometimes regional arterial insufficiency (e.g. occlusions of coronary artery causing myocardial infarction, carotid or vertebral artery causing stroke, spinal artery causing hemi- or quadriplegia, renal artery causing renal failure); subclavian artery occlusion may cause differential blood pressure in either arm; aortic regurgitation; cardiac tamponade; sudden death</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chest X-ray: widened mediastinum, occasionally with left pleural effusion</li>
<li>Transoesophageal echocardiogram, computed tomography (CT) scan, or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan: confirms dissection</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="comments">Comments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Type A dissections involve the ascending aorta and are usually treated surgically. Type B dissections involve the arch and/or descending aorta and are usually managed medically or with an endovascular stent
(Table 11.1), but its mechanisms are complex. In acute pulmonary oedema and orthopnoea, dyspnoea is due mainly to the elevated left atrial pressure that characterizes left heart failure (Box 11.9). This produces a corresponding elevation of the pulmonary capillary pressure and increases transudation into the lungs, which become oedematous and stiff. Oxygenation of blood in the pulmonary arterioles is reduced causing hypoxaemia, and this, together with the extra effort required to ventilate the stiff lungs, causes dyspnoea. In exertional dyspnoea, other mechanisms are also important.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exertional-dyspnoea">Exertional dyspnoea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exertional-dyspnoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most troublesome symptom in heart failure (Box 11.10). Exercise causes a sharp increase in left atrial pressure and this contributes to the pathogenesis of dyspnoea by causing pulmonary congestion (see above). However, the severity of dyspnoea does not correlate closely with exertional left atrial pressure, and other factors must therefore be important. These include respiratory muscle fatigue and the effects of exertional acidosis on</p>
<p>Box 11.8 Pulmonary embolism</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="typical-patient">Typical patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#typical-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Recent surgery, lower limb fracture or long-distance air travel; obese; sedentary; heart failure; malignancy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-symptoms">Major symptoms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-symptoms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Chest pain, dyspnoea, haemoptysis, syncope</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="major-signs">Major signs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#major-signs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Peripheral emboli: pleural rub</li>
<li>Large, central emboli: tachycardia, hypotension, cyanosis, raised jugular venous pressure (JVP)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>D-Dimer: a negative D-dimer in a low-risk patient makes pulmonary embolism very unlikely</li>
<li>ECG: sinus tachycardia; right bundle branch block (RBBB); classical 'S1, Q3, T3' pattern uncommon</li>
<li>Chest X-ray: normal; wedge-shaped peripheral opacification; absent pulmonary vascular markings</li>
<li>Echocardiogram: dilated right heart in some cases of large central pulmonary embolism</li>
<li>CT pulmonary angiogram: has superseded V/Q scanning as the diagnostic test of choice</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="comments">Comments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#comments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Suspect pulmonary embolism in patients with unexplained hypoxia. Thrombolyic therapy should be considered for patients with pulmonary embolism associated with shock and/or a dilated right heart on echo. Patients with no risk factors for pulmonary embolism should be investigated for prothrombotic states.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 11.1 Causes of heart failure</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">Ventricular &lt;br&gt; pathophysiology</th><th style="text-align: left;">Clinical examples</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Restricted filling</td><td style="text-align: left;">Mitral stenosis &lt;br&gt; Constrictive pericarditis &lt;br&gt; Restrictive cardiomyopathy &lt;br&gt; Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Pressure loading</td><td style="text-align: left;">Hypertension &lt;br&gt; Aortic stenosis &lt;br&gt; Coarctation of the aorta</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Volume loading</td><td style="text-align: left;">Mitral regurgitation &lt;br&gt; Aortic regurgitation</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Contractile impairment</td><td style="text-align: left;">Coronary artery disease &lt;br&gt; Dilated cardiomyopathy &lt;br&gt; Myocarditis</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Arrhythmia</td><td style="text-align: left;">Severe bradycardia &lt;br&gt; Severe tachycardia</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Box 11.9 Acute left ventricular failure
Typical patient</p>
<ul>
<li>Patient with acute myocardial infarction or known left ventricular disease</li>
</ul>
